question_text: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for vesicles and increased skin fragility involving the face, scalp, and dorsal hands, as shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a hereditary or acquired blistering disease caused by excess circulating porphyrins (Option D). Patients present with vesicles, bullae, and skin fragility on sun-exposed skin, most commonly on the face, dorsal hands (as seen in this patient), and scalp; photosensitivity is the hallmark of the disease. Other features include hyperpigmentation, milia (tiny inclusion cysts), hypertrichosis, and alopecia. Up to 50% of patients with sporadic PCT have hepatitis C virus infection.
